abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Western Savannah
            Development Project for Sudan were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory, project sustainability was uncertain, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            deficient. Some lessons learned included: complex project
            design with too many components complicates project
            implementation, particularity in coordination, and should be
            avoided. However, to the extent that related developments
            are needed in a number of different areas, it is important
            to analyze the relationships among those and ensure that
            linkages are understood and maintained throughout
            implementation. Cost recovery for the water yards could be
            further improved if the service was made more reliable.
            However, full cost recovery of water supply from deep
            boreholes for human and animal consumption remains illusory
            if the drain on families' cash income may be as high as
            30 percent. Insistence on this will cause concentration of
            populations on the areas where free water is available,
            leading to land degradation. To the extent that the benefits
            of water yards are largely environmental, an element of
            subsidization is warranted.
